awd_titl_txt: Concentrating on Completing and Competing in the STEM Technical Workforce in Urban Polynesia: C3 UP
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cohorts Proposal Concentrating on Completing and Competing in the STEM Technical Workforce in Urban Polynesia (C4-UP) project is providing scholarships and programmatic support for financially needy, talented, Native Hawaiian and other students at University of Hawaii Kapiolani Community College (KCC).  Cohort support activities include Hawaiian cultural enrichment, peer mentoring, community service and research opportunities, internships, conferences, and engagement with STEM industry representatives. Broader impacts are provided by sharing these results with local K-12 partners, community colleges and baccalaureate programs, the NSF Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP), other minority serving institutions, and other national educational organizations. A total of 110 scholarships are being awarded to annual cohorts of KCC sophomores, transferring juniors, and completing seniors. The students who have transferred will mentor each new KCC cohort, facilitating the transfer process and improving retention. KCC Academic Advisors and Job and Career Placement Specialists are assisting with transfer and workforce entry. Among goals to recruit and support KCC students, faculty/staff from KCC and UHM are assessing improvement in students' abilities to "write-to-learn" science over the course of program participation.

The intellectual merit of this project is to build and evaluate an evidence-based model to support students as they complete Kapiolani Community College's (KCC) two-year Associate in Science in Natural Sciences degree, successfully transfer, persist and complete UH Mânoa (UHM) STEM baccalaureate degrees, and compete in the STEM technical workforce, thus systematically increasing the participation and success of students in STEM majors and careers. Institutional researchers are evaluating the impact of program strategies by adapting the Writing To Learn (WTL) in STEM research framework with C4 scholars at KCC and UHM.  The WTL framework emphasizes that learning is no longer understood as the acquisition of knowledge, but as the construction of understanding and meaning as a result of social interaction, such as those between students and faculty, peer mentors, and cohort members.  Formative and summative evaluation will be conducted on the following C4 scholar success measures: 1) course success (earning a C or better, earning a B or better); 2) number of C4 scholars with grade point averages of 3.0 or higher; 3) re-enrollment fall-to-spring and fall-to-fall; 4) cohort time to degree completion, transfer, baccalaureate completion, and entrance into workforce.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the project was to develop financial and programmatic supports to assist talented, low income Native Hawaiian and other URM students to complete the College’s two-year Associate in Science in Natural Science (ASNS) degree, successfully transfer and persist in their junior and senior years, complete STEM baccalaureate degrees, and be better prepared to compete in the STEM technical workforce.     
Kapiolani Community College S-STEM scholars were provided annual scholarships that covered tuition costs for full-time enrollment at the college. Upon transfer to the four-year university, the scholarship amount doubled, which covered 60% of the tuition. In addition to financial support, the project put into place mentorship, writing support, and other programmatic supports.  

One of the goals of the grant was to support 50 S-STEM participants; 30 of which must graduate with a bachelor’s degree in a STEM discipline, and 25 of which must enter the workforce and/or graduate school by the end of year 5. By the end of this program, 64 S-STEM participants were supported; 31 completed their two-year associate degree and graduated with a four-year baccalaureate STEM degree; 18 out of the 31 joined the workforce, 6 were still in graduate school at the end of the project, and 7 could not be tracked after graduating.
To evaluate the efficacy of project overall in supporting S-STEM students through their academic journey, three comparisons were done comparing course success between the S-STEM scholars and students pursuing the same degree (ASNS) who were not supported by S-STEM:

  1. 91% of the S-STEM students earned a grade C or higher during the last two semesters at Kapiolani compared to 72% of the non-S-STEM students pursuing the ASNS;
  2. 48% of the S-STEM students earned a grade C or higher after transferring to a four-year institution in STEM at the University of Hawaii at Manoa compared to 41% of the non-S-STEM students;
  3. 46% of the S-STEM students earned a grade B or higher after transferring to a four-year institution in STEM at the University of Hawaii at Manoa compared to 36% of the non-S-STEM students;

Mentorship of the community college S-STEM scholars by those who had transferred to bachelor’s degree programs was promoted through in-person events and an online website.  Each year the program hosted “Meet and Greet” events on the university campus that allowed for mentorship among the S-STEM scholars within specific STEM disciplines.  These events also allowed the community college students to become familiar with the university campus prior to transferring.  An S-STEM Campus Connect website was also developed to foster these mentoring relationships.  Unfortunately, these activities did not show measurable impacts, especially due to the pandemic moving the in-person mentoring events online and bringing a new set of challenges to participants.
Student writing support was implemented in courses from three different science disciplines using the Writing-to-Learn approach (WTL) to make students thinking and learning visible and assessable. In Calculus-based Physics courses, it was found that there is a substantiate agreement (Cohen Kappa=0.70) between the grade earned by students and the presence of an accurately written method that describes all the required steps of problem solving. There is a 94.6% probability (Sensitivity) that students are successful (>70%) if they write out all their steps correctly following the method. There is an 80.6% probability (Specificity) that students are not successful (<70%) if they do not write out all their steps correctly or do it partially while attempting to follow the method. In addition, 81.8% of the students enrolled in WTL sections stay in the course while only 67.9% of the students in non- WTL sections remain enrolled and active through the end of the semester, and 77.3% of the students enrolled in WTL sections earned a C or higher compared to only 43.3% of the students in non-WTL sections.
This S-STEM project aimed to generate knowledge with respect to the most effective strategies to improve students’ success. The indicators used were the cumulative GPA prior to joining the cohort and the cumulative GPA of the last semester at Kapi’olani before transferring to a four-year institution in STEM. The treatments used in the analysis were: the use of academic support services, career counseling/job placement, participation in community building, field trips, internships, meetings/conferences, mentoring, research opportunities, and seminars. A regression/ANOVA was performed again on all S-STEM participants in addition to the newly engaged students this past academic year in order to identify which of these activities had the most impact on students’ GPA. No statistical differences were found (p>0.05) for any of the activities students participated in.
In summary, the scholarship and associated activities were shown to improve student grade performance at the community college and the university level, and promoted transfer and graduation in STEM disciplines.  However, no single activity was shown to have a significant impact on GPA.  


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Amy Yamashiro
por.por_txt_cntn:
The primary goal of the project was to develop financial and programmatic supports to assist talented, low income Native Hawaiian and other URM students to complete the College’s two-year Associate in Science in Natural Science (ASNS) degree, successfully transfer and persist in their junior and senior years, complete STEM baccalaureate degrees, and be better prepared to compete in the STEM technical workforce.

91% of the S-STEM students earned a grade C or higher during the last two semesters at Kapiolani compared to 72% of the non-S-STEM students pursuing the ASNS;

46% of the S-STEM students earned a grade B or higher after transferring to a four-year institution in STEM at the University of Hawaii at Manoa compared to 36% of the non-S-STEM students;
